pageData.text: Explore the concept of density through four activities. In the first activity, the densities of three regular solids will be determined. In the second activity, the densities of water and sucrose solutions will be determined from graphs of mass versus volume. Using the information collected in the first two activities, you will predict and test if the solids sink or float in the sucrose solutions. In the final activity, the density of a beverage will be used to calculate the concentration of sucrose.

pageData.title: Time Requirements

pageData.text: The lab may be paused at any time and continued later. If the lab is paused prior to completion, ensure that all liquids are sealed to prevent evaporation.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Calculate the densities of regular solids.
Determine the densities of solutions by plotting mass versus volume.
Predict whether objects will sink or float in different solutions based on the densities of the solutions and objects.
Determine the concentration of sucrose in a beverage based on a graph of known sucrose concentration densities.

pageData.text: In the 200s BCE, the king of Syracuse in ancient Greece asked a goldsmith to make a crown of pure gold and gave him a specific amount of gold to use. Upon receiving the finished crown, the king suspected it was not, in fact, pure gold and that the goldsmith had embezzled some of the original gold. So, the king sought the help of scientist Archimedes to prove his new crown was not pure gold without damaging it. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>It is said that the inspiration to solve this mystery struck Archimedes during one of his baths as he filled the tub to the brim and spilled water everywhere upon getting in. The water leaving the tub, being displaced by his body, was proportional to the mass of his body; he therefore surmised that if the crown really was pure gold, it would displace the same volume of water as a sample of gold equal in mass to the original gold given to the smith. The property of matter Archimedes employed was density: gold has a higher density than most other metals. When the crown displaced less water than the pure gold sample, he demonstrated empirically that the crown was less dense than pure gold and the goldsmith had lied.

pageData.altText: A stylized illustration of a crown next to a bar of gold.
pageData.desc: A stylized illustration of a crown next to a bar of gold.

pageData.text: Density is a physical property of matter that is based on mass and volume of the substance. Mass and volume are <button class='glossary-text'>extensive properties</button>, meaning that they are dependent on the quantity of matter. However, density is an <button class='glossary-text'>intensive property</button> and does not change with quantity. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Density is a derived unit, meaning that it is composed of two basic units. These units are mass and volume. Density can be defined as mass per unit of volume. To calculate the density of an object, the following equation can be used: the mathematical expression for density is <button class='glossary-text'>D = M/V</button>. The mass (M) in this calculation is expressed in grams (g), and volume (V) is expressed in cubic centimeters (cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup>). When describing volumes, milliliter (mL) units may replace cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> because the two units are fundamentally equivalent. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Density and weight are not the same value. For instance, some people might say that steel weighs more than sand. However, a huge mound of sand obviously weighs more than one steel marble. The amount of a substance plays a big role in this case. It would be more accurate to compare masses of steel and sand that have equal volumes. In doing so, it will be determined that 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> of steel has a greater mass than that of 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> of sand, since the total weight of the steel is higher, yet the volume is the same between the steel and the sand. In other words, steel does not weigh more than sand; rather, steel is denser than sand.

pageData.question: 1 kg of water completely fills a 1000 mL (1 L) bottle. 1 kg of mercury metal only fills the same bottle with 74 mL of liquid. Which of the following best describes the density of water compared to that of mercury?

options.text: Water is less dense than mercury because it takes more water to achieve the same mass as mercury.
Water is denser than mercury because there is more water than mercury even though both substances weigh the same.
Water and mercury have the same density because they have the same mass.
It is not possible to determine relative densities with the information given.
Water and mercury have the same density because they are both in a liquid state.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Density is calculated by dividing mass per unit volume. If the mass of each substance is the same, the substance with the greater volume will have the smaller density. Water is less dense than mercury because it takes more than twice as much volume for water to match the same mass as mercury.

pageData.question: 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> block of brass has a mass of 8.5 grams. Assuming each of the following has a volume equal to that of the block, which is denser than brass?

options.text: 19.0 grams of uranium
2.4 grams of moon rock
0.0025 grams of feathers
0.96 grams of apple
1.5 grams of wood

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Density is calculated by dividing mass per unit volume. If all the volumes of each substance are equal, the substance with the greatest mass also has the greatest density.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Density and weight are not the same value. Take sand and steel, for example. Some people might say that steel weighs more than sand; however, a huge mound of sand weighs much more than one steel marble. The amount of a substance plays a big role in this example. To more accurately determine the difference between sand and steel, the volume of each substance should be equal and the masses of each compared. Doing so will reveal that 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> of steel has a mass of 7.85 grams and 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> of sand has a mass of 1.60 grams: the total weight of the steel is higher, yet the volume is the same between the steel and the sand. Therefore, steel does not weigh more than sand, but rather steel is denser than sand.
hintData.alt: A pile of sand next to a metal sphere.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Density and weight are not the same value. Take sand and steel, for example. Some people might say that steel weighs more than sand; however, a huge mound of sand weighs much more than one steel marble. The amount of a substance plays a big role in this example. To more accurately determine the difference between sand and steel, the volume of each substance should be equal and the masses of each compared. Doing so will reveal that 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> of steel has a mass of 7.85 grams and 1 cm<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup> of sand has a mass of 1.60 grams: the total weight of the steel is higher, yet the volume is the same between the steel and the sand. Therefore, steel does not weigh more than sand, but rather steel is denser than sand.
hintData.alt: A pile of sand next to a metal sphere.

pageData.text: One of the tools to determine unknown values is a best-fit line (or <button class='glossary-text'>regression line</button>), a line within a scatter plot. This will show the linear relationship of data. A best-fit line allows data points that were not collected during an experiment to be predicted. The line created by plotting the known points and connecting them with a linear line allows one value to be determined by reading the other. For instance, if we plot the mass versus volume of known objects, the linear line obtained by connecting the known values can be used to determine the unknown values. If the chart has mass on one axis, we can look at a certain mass, go to the line, and read the corresponding volume from the other axis. Since most experiments have some experimental error, a best-fit line helps average out these errors. To create these lines, they can be calculated with statistical formulas for regression lines. Most spreadsheet applications, such as Microsoft Excel<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>, are able to perform these calculations.

The equation of a best-fit line is typically represented as <button class='glossary-text'>y = mx + b</button>, in which y represents a data point on the y-axis, x represents a data point on the x-axis, m represents the slope of the line, and b represents the y-intercept (i.e., where the line crosses the y-axis). When a graph of mass versus volume is created in this experiment, the y-intercept must be set to zero. This is because when there is no mass, there should also be no volume, and vice versa. The equation used is y = mx. The mass is graphed on the y-axis, and the volume is graphed on the x-axis. This equation actually shows that mass = (m)volume since we determined that the graph needs to go through zero. Rearrangement of the equation to isolate m (the slope) results in the equation: mass/volume = m. Here we divided both sides of the equation by volume. Mass/volume is the mathematical formula for density. Thus, in a graph of mass versus volume, the slope (m) represents the density of the substance. In this investigation, you will be using regular solids. These are solid objects with a regular shape, such as a cube or a cylinder. The regular shape will make it easier to determine the volume of the object compared with an object with an irregular shape.

pageData.question: Given the equation of a best-fit line is typically represented as y = mx + b, which of the following graphs would allow you to calculate density using the slope of the best-fit line?

options.text: volume on the x-axis; mass on the y-axis
mass on the x-axis; volume on the y-axis
mass on the x-axis; density on the y-axis
Mass and volume can be on either axis as long as the y-intercept equals zero.
Mass and volume can be on either axis as long as the x-intercept equals zero.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Density is calculated as mass over volume. The slope of a best-fit line is calculated as y over x (rise over run). Therefore, the slope of a best-fit line will equal density if the mass is on the y axis and the volume is on the x axis. The y-intercept equals zero because if there is no mass, there should also be no volume, and vice versa.

pageData.question: Justine is plotting the data collected from her 3 cylinders on a graph of mass (g) versus volume (mL). If one of her data points is plotted at (3, 1.5), which of the following best describes this cylinder?

options.text: The density of the cylinder is 2 g/mL.
The density of the cylinder is 0.5 g/mL.
The mass of the cylinder is 1.5 g.
The volume of the cylinder is 3 mL.
The density of the cylinder is 4.5 g/mL.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Coordinates are written (y, x). Because Justine’s graph is of mass versus volume, mass is on the y-axis and volume is on the x-axis. A data point at (3, 1.5) represents a cylinder with a mass of 3 grams and a volume of 1.5 mL, which gives a density of 2 g/mL.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The equation of a best-fit line is typically represented as y = mx + b, in which y represents a data point on the y-axis, x represents a data point on the x-axis, m represents the slope of the line, and b represents the y-intercept (i.e., where the line crosses the y-axis). When a graph of mass versus volume is created in this experiment, the y-intercept must be set to zero. This is because when there is no mass, there should also be no volume, and vice versa. The equation then becomes y = mx. Slope (m) is calculated as y/x; in other words, rise over run. This formula is similar in structure to the formula for density, mass/volume. So, if mass is graphed on the y-axis and volume is graphed on the x-axis, the slope of a best-fit line of such a graph will represent the mathematical formula for density.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The equation of a best-fit line is typically represented as y = mx + b, in which y represents a data point on the y-axis, x represents a data point on the x-axis, m represents the slope of the line, and b represents the y-intercept (i.e., where the line crosses the y-axis). When a graph of mass versus volume is created in this experiment, the y-intercept must be set to zero. This is because when there is no mass, there should also be no volume, and vice versa. The equation then becomes y = mx. Slope (m) is calculated as y/x; in other words, rise over run. This formula is similar in structure to the formula for density, mass/volume. So, if mass is graphed on the y-axis and volume is graphed on the x-axis, the slope of a best-fit line of such a graph will represent the mathematical formula for density.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Prepare 7 different sucrose solutions and an uncarbonated beverage for Activity 4. In Activity 1, measure the mass of a cylinder. Calculate its volume. Calculate the density of the cylinder. This activity is repeated for all 3 cylinders. In Activity 2, measure the mass of a sucrose solution in 5-mL increments. Graph mass versus volume for the solution and create a linear trend line. Determine the density of the solution from the slope of the trend line. This activity is repeated for all 7 solutions. In Activity 3, predict whether each cylinder will sink or float in each sucrose solution. Test your predictions. In Activity 4, graph the sucrose percentage versus density using Activity 2 data. Measure the mass of your chosen beverage in 5-mL increments. Graph the mass versus volume for the beverage and create a linear trend line. Determine the density of the beverage from the slope of the line and the percentage of sucrose in the beverage.
pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Prepare 7 different sucrose solutions and an uncarbonated beverage for Activity 4. In Activity 1, measure the mass of a cylinder. Calculate its volume. Calculate the density of the cylinder. This activity is repeated for all 3 cylinders. In Activity 2, measure the mass of a sucrose solution in 5-mL increments. Graph mass versus volume for the solution and create a linear trend line. Determine the density of the solution from the slope of the trend line. This activity is repeated for all 7 solutions. In Activity 3, predict whether each cylinder will sink or float in each sucrose solution. Test your predictions. In Activity 4, graph the sucrose percentage versus density using Activity 2 data. Measure the mass of your chosen beverage in 5-mL increments. Graph the mass versus volume for the beverage and create a linear trend line. Determine the density of the beverage from the slope of the line and the percentage of sucrose in the beverage.

<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely. Observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Ice floats on water. How does the density of ice compare to the density of water?

options.text: Water is denser than ice.
Ice is denser than water.
They have the same density because they are both made of the same compound.
Water lifts the denser ice because water is warmer than ice and heat rises.
Ice is denser than water but as it melts it pushes to the surface.

assestmentData.question: You have four blocks of iron. Block A weighs 5 g, block B weighs 3 g, block C weighs 18 g, and block D weighs 0.5 g. Which block has the highest density?

options.text: The blocks have the same density.
Block A
Block B
Block C
Block D

assestmentData.question: Two plastic bags are filled with water. Bag A has salt added to the water; bag B does not. Both are sealed and placed in a container of water, where they float. Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Bag A floats at a lower depth than bag B.
Bag B floats at a lower depth than bag A.
The bags float at equal depths.
The depth at which each bag floats depends on its volume.
The depth at which each bag floats depends on its mass.

assestmentData.question: Two objects, A and B, both have the same mass, but B has a larger volume. Which of the following best describes the density of the objects?

options.text: Object B is less dense than object A.
Object A is less dense than object B.
Since they have the same mass, they have the same density.
The data are inconclusive.
The density only differs when the objects are placed in water.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following has the same mass as 1 kg of sand?

options.text: 1 kg of feathers
2 kg of milk
3 kg of pebbles
2 kg of flour
0.5 kg of clay

assestmentData.question: The gravity on Mars is 62% less than the gravity on Earth. If a lead object and a wooden object are both transported from Earth to Mars, which of the following best describes their densities?

options.text: The density of each object remains the same as it was on Earth.
The lead object has the same density as the wooden object.
The wooden object is 62 times denser than the lead object.
The lead object’s density is 62% the density of the wooden object.
The wooden object’s density is 62% the density of the lead object.

assestmentData.question: In a graph of mass versus volume, where the mass is graphed on the y-axis and the volume is graphed on the x-axis, which of the following values of a best-fit line represents the density of a substance?

options.text: slope (m)
y-intercept (b)
y
x
x + b

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the ultimate purpose of the beverage used in Activity 4 of this investigation?

options.text: to determine its sugar content
to determine its density
to determine its percent change in mass
to determine its percent change in volume
to determine its percent carbonation

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Label each of seven cups with “0%,” “10%,” “20%,” “30%,” “40%,” “50%,” and “60%” sucrose.
Label one cup “beverage.”
If a carbonated beverage will be used in Activity 4, open the beverage to allow the soda to flatten (degas) for about 24 hours.

Prepare the following sucrose solutions (reported in mass by mass percentage) by mixing the indicated mass of sucrose in 50 mL (50 g) purified water in the appropriately labeled cup. Use the electronic balance to measure the sugar. Use the graduated cylinder to measure the water.
Stir the solutions thoroughly with a spoon until all of the sucrose has dissolved.
There must be no carbonation in the beverage when Activity 4 is being performed.

The sucrose in the 50% and 60% solutions will not dissolve easily. It may help to warm the solutions slightly in the microwave for short burst of 10 seconds each. Then stir and allow the solutions to cool to room temperature. <span class=bodyParaLineBreak>As the concentrations of sucrose increase, the solutions will become slightly yellow. However, the solutions will remain transparent when the sucrose has fully dissolved.

If the solutions will not be used immediately, cover them with plastic wrap and store them for later use. Solutions should be used within 48 hours of preparation. Note: In order to obtain the best results, check the volume after letting the solution sit for an extended period of time. Adjust the total volume should this be needed.
In Activity 1, you will measure the mass of each cylinder, and calculate the volume of each cylinder using height and diameter measurements. You will then calculate the density of each cylinder.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determining the Densities of Regular Solids (7 steps)
pages.title: Determining the Densities of Regular Solids (7 steps)

pageData.text: Using a balance, measure the mass of each cylinder in grams. Record the results in Data Table 1.
Using a ruler, measure the height (h) and diameter (d) of each cylinder in centimeters. Record these measurements in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: diagram showing the dimentions of a cylinder, with “d” for diameter and “h” for height
pageData.desc: diagram showing the dimentions of a cylinder, with “d” for diameter and “h” for height

pageData.text: The diameter of a circle is equal to twice its radius (d = 2r or r = d ⁄ 2). Find the radius of each cylinder by dividing the diameter of the circle by 2.
Record these dimensions in Data Table 1.
Calculate the volume of each cylinder using the equation V = πr<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>h. The approximate value of π is 3.14.
Calculate the density of each cylinder by dividing its measured mass by its calculated volume ().
Record the results in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will determine the density of 7 different sucrose solutions ranging from 0% to 60% sucrose. You will calculate the mass of each solution at different volumes, then plot the data collected for each type of solution on a scatter-plot graph of mass versus volume. You will create a best-fit line (linear trend line) for each data set on the same graph. You will end the activity by recording the equation of each best-fit line and determining the density of each sucrose solution.

pages.title: Determining the Densities of Solutions (15 steps)

pageData.text: Weigh an empty 50-mL graduated cylinder. Record the mass in Data Table 2.
Add 5 mL of water (0% sucrose) to the 50-mL graduated cylinder. Use the pipet to add or remove small quantities of liquid so that the water is exactly at the 5-mL mark.
Record the Mass of Solution + Graduated Cylinder in Data Table 2.
Add more water until the cylinder contains 10 mL volume. Use the appropriate pipet to adjust the volume.
Record the Mass of Solution + Graduated Cylinder in Data Table 2.
Continue adding water in increments of 5 mL, and determine the mass of 15 mL, 20 mL, and 25 mL water. Record all of the data in Data Table 2.
Calculate the corresponding Mass of Solution for each volume of water and record this information in Data Table 2.
Use a graphing program to create a scatter-plot graph with the mass of the solution on the y-axis and the volume of the solution on the x-axis.

On the graph, create a best-fit line (linear trend line) based on the data points. Ensure that the y-intercept of the best-fit line is set to 0.Record the equation for the best-fit line in Data Table 3.

Determine the slope from the equation of the best-fit line, and record the value. This is the density of the solution. The units will be in g/mL. Record the slope (average density) for water in Data Table 3.
Return the solution to the appropriately labeled cup.
Rinse the graduated cylinder with purified water, and shake out any remaining water droplets.
Shake any solution out of the pipet so that it is dry.
Repeat steps 1–13 for each of the sucrose solutions (10%, 20%, 30%, 40%, 50%, and 60%).
Plot all of the data on the same graph. At the end of Activity 2, there should be seven sets of data with seven best-fit lines on one graph.

Based on the calculated densities of the cylinders from Activity 1 and the solutions from Activity 2, you will predict whether each cylinder will float or sink in each of the 7 sucrose solutions. You will then test your predictions by placing the cylinders in the different solutions.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Will It Sink or Float? (6 steps)
pages.title: Will It Sink or Float? (6 steps)

pageData.text: Based on the calculated densities of the cylinders from Activity 1 and solutions from Activity 2, predict whether each cylinder will float or sink in each of the sucrose solutions and water. Record the predictions in Data Table 4.

Test the predictions by placing the aluminum(silver-colored) cylinder in at least the following two solutions: the solution in which you predict the aluminum is most likely to sink, and the one in which you predict the aluminum is most likely to float.
Remove excess solution from the cylinder before you place it in the next solution.
Record the results in Data Table 4.
If the predictions were incorrect, test the aluminum cylinders in other solutions.
Repeat steps 1–4 for the acrylic (clear) and polyethylene (white) cylinders.
After testing the cylinders, rinse them with fresh water and dry them.

In Activity 4, you will determine the sucrose concentration of a natural sugar beverage of your choice. You will start by creating a scatter-plot graph of sucrose percentage versus density, including a best-fit line, using the data from Activity 2. This graph will be used later in the activity. You will then use the same procedure as that of Activity 2 to determine the mass of the beverage at different volumes, graph the mass versus volume, draw a best-fit line, and determine the density of the beverage. By plotting the density of the beverage along the best-fit line of the sucrose percentage versus density graph you created at the beginning of the activity, you will determine the approximate sucrose concentration of the beverage.

pages.title:
A
 Determination of the Sugar Content in a Beverage (8 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of the Sugar Content in a Beverage (8 steps)

typeBefore.text: The beverage must be completely flat, or decarbonated, to accurately determine the concentration of sucrose.

pageData.text: Use a graphing program and the data from Activity 2 to create a scatter-plot of Sucrose Percentage versus Density.
Use the same procedure as that of Activity 2 to determine the mass of 5 mL, 10 mL, 15 mL, 20 mL, and 25 mL of the beverage.
Record all of the data in Data Table 5.
Use a graphing program to plot the mass of the solution on the y-axis and the volume of the solution on the x-axis.
On the graph, draw a best-fit line through all of the points.
Determine the slope of the best-fit line and read the value. This is an average of all five data points with units in g/mL.
Record the slope (average density) below the data table.

Use the graph created in step 1 to determine the percentage of sucrose in the beverage.
  1. Determine the density of the beverage from the y-axis.
  2. Draw a horizontal line from this point across the graph until it intercepts the best-fit line.
  3. Draw a vertical line from the intersection of the horizontal line and best-fit line to the x-axis.
  4. Record the percentage of sucrose from the intersection of the vertical line and the x-axis. This is the percentage of sucrose in the beverage.

text: Dispose of the sucrose solutions in the sink.
Clean and dry all of the equipment; return items to the equipment kit.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.title: Questions
text: In Activity 4, the percentage of sucrose in a beverage was determined using density; however, many commercial beverages are made with high fructose corn syrup and not sucrose. Even beverages such as juice are not primarily sucrose.
nestedOrderList: Is the percentage concentration of sucrose determined in this activity accurate? Why or why not? If it is not, what could be done to make it more accurate?
Beyond sucrose type, what other confounding factors may exist in the determination of percentage concentration of sucrose? What were potential sources of error?

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Prepare 7 different sucrose solutions and an uncarbonated beverage for Activity 4. In Activity 1, measure the mass of a cylinder. Calculate its volume. Calculate the density of the cylinder. This activity is repeated for all 3 cylinders. In Activity 2, measure the mass of a sucrose solution in 5-mL increments. Graph mass versus volume for the solution and create a linear trend line. Determine the density of the solution from the slope of the trend line. This activity is repeated for all 7 solutions. In Activity 3, predict whether each cylinder will sink or float in each sucrose solution. Test your predictions. In Activity 4, graph the sucrose percentage versus density using Activity 2 data. Measure the mass of your chosen beverage in 5-mL increments. Graph the mass versus volume for the beverage and create a linear trend line. Determine the density of the beverage from the slope of the line and the percentage of sucrose in the beverage.
diagram showing the dimentions of a cylinder, with “d” for diameter and “h” for height
pageData.content: Figure 1. The dimensions of a cylinder

data.title: D = m/V
data.content: Density equation where m is the mass in grams and V is the volume in mL or cc<sup class=bodySupscript>3</sup>

data.title: Extensive property
data.content: Dependent on the quantity of matter

data.title: Intensive property
data.content: Does not change with quantity of matter

data.title: Regression line
data.content: Best-fit line within a scatter plot

data.title: y = mx + b
data.content: Best-fit line equation where y is a data point on the y-axis, x is a data point on the x-axis, m is the slope of the line, b is the y-intercept (i.e., where the line crosses the y-axis).
